title: How to get the most out of a social media influencer
text:
Industry experts say using analytics and artificial intelligence is important for corporates to make sure they are getting the most return on investment through influencer marketing.

L &A Social Media founder and CEO Gina Lednyak said before any brand starts working with influencers it must decide what are the business goals it would like to achieve.

Quality is critical

She said there are three keys for a business to ensure a successful partnership with influencers: check their following and ensure that the demographics of the followers is aligned with the demographic the brand would like to reach; ensure the influencer is aligned on brand values; and use data/analytics.

Brands are looking for those people who can curate their products into peoples' lives, not just appear to be trying to sell a product. — Tayran Williams, founder and CEO, theright.fit

"A lot of brands simply choose the influencer with the largest following, but the quality and relevancy of the following is much more critical," she said.

She warns that corporates need to be aware of someone who is partnered with too many brands, as it it becomes unauthentic, and people might not believe the influencer believes in the brand.

"The Aussie market is intelligent. We have extremely high digital penetration. We can sense when a product does not feel naturally aligned to an influencer, and it really puts consumers off," she said.

Advertisement

With Instagram getting rid of "likes", Ms Lednyak said it is important that a company look at the analytics in the same way a company would ask a magazine for a media kit before placing advertising.

"Brands might choose an influencer that fits their target demographic, but the followers might not fit the brand's demographic," she said.

Ms Lednyak said influencers are only one part of the overall social media strategy for companies.

Companies are able to achieve more with these targeted results and on a smaller budget, she said.

"Having a solid social strategy is really important and influencers is part of that. A brand has to decide what parts of the story do they want to tell on our own, and what part do we want the influencer to tell?"

With more than 1 billion users and a large network of influencers posting millions of sponsored pictures each year, Instagram has become the most important influencer marketing channel, ahead of Facebook or Twitter.

The use of analytics and AI is on the rise in the quest to match product to influencer.

theright.fit platform, a global marketplace to connect talent with brands, provides a detailed breakdown of its 10,000-odd influencers that includes things like the age and gender of the influencers' followers, where they are located, and growth over time.

Advertisement

Founder and CEO Tayran Williams said having robust data which illustrates key audience demographics, sentiment and historic engagement allows a brand to plan ahead, and be more targeted with its marketing content and spend.

She points to engagement rates (or ER) as a vital social media metric enabling brands and agencies to measure the effectiveness of influencer actions and better understand how their audience engages with their content.

ER is the percentage of the influencer’s audience that responds and reacts with "likes", "comments", and "shares".

"Brands are looking for those people who can curate their products into peoples' lives, not just appear to be holding and trying to sell a product," she said.

"It allows a brand to tap into this audience, rather than the brand taking the time and energy to build up that audience themselves, which is much harder as they are not an independent voice."
description: It's big business with the influencer marketing industry tipped to grow to as much as $22 billion in three years.
